channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2014 The New York Times Company

item.title: Koreans, Even in the North, Begin to Bid Farewell to Victims of a Disaster
item.description: The country began bidding farewell to the hundreds of young lives lost to last week’s ferry accident, and even normally icy North Korea sent condolences.
item.dc:creator: By CHOE SANG-HUN and JIHA HAM
item.media:credit: Woohae Cho for The New York Times
item.media:description: Victims of the ferry sinking were mourned on Wednesday while many relatives still waited to identify their loved ones.

item.title: Colombia’s President Reinstates a Mayor He Ousted
item.description: President Juan Manuel Santos on Wednesday restored Gustavo Petro as the mayor of Bogotá a month after removing him from office to comply with a decision by the inspector general.
item.dc:creator: By WILLIAM NEUMAN
item.media:description: Gustavo Petro, center, arrived at city hall in Bogotá, Colombia, on Wednesday after being reinstated as mayor of the city.

item.title: Eastern Europe Frets About NATO’s Ability to Curb Russia
item.description: An alliance hollowed out by years of military cuts has awakened to altered circumstances involving Ukraine and is not prepared to counter a newly assertive Moscow, its own leaders acknowledge.
item.dc:creator: By STEVEN ERLANGER
item.media:description: Two NATO crew members during a patrol over Romania and Poland last week, part of new efforts to monitor airspace along the border with Ukraine.

item.title: Palestinian Rivals Announce Unity Pact, Drawing U.S. and Israeli Rebuke
item.description: The deal between Hamas and the Palestine Liberation Organization appeared more serious than past attempts, experts said, and came as hopes faded for a resolution to peace negotiations with Israel.
item.dc:creator: By JODI RUDOREN and MICHAEL R. GORDON

item.title: Lens Blog: Winning With Compassion and Respect
item.description: The winner of this year’s 2014 Getty Images and Chris Hondros Fund Award honors Daniel Berehulak for his sense of compassion and respect for his subjects.
item.category: ictures of The Year International contest
item.dc:creator: By JAMES ESTRIN
item.media:credit: Daniel Berehulak for The New York Times
item.media:description: Afghan women testing the appetite of their children, as part of an assessment of their malnutrition levels, at an outreach therapeutic feeding program. Oct. 13, 2013.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: 25 Years After Tiananmen, Calls for Officials to Disclose Assets Still Unmet
item.description: On April 18, 1989, protesting students demanded that Chinese leaders reveal their financial assets. Twenty-five years later, on April 18, 2014, that demand remained unmet as four more members of a group calling for the public disclosure of officials’ assets were sentenced to prison.
item.category: Central Commission for Discipline Inspection (Communist Party of China)
item.dc:creator: By DIDI KIRSTEN TATLOW
item.media:description: Students demonstrating in Tiananmen Square during the 1989 democracy movement.

item.title: Obama’s First Order of Business in Tokyo: Sushi From the Master
item.description: President Obama and Prime Minister Shinzo Abe had dinner at Sukiyabashi Jiro, whose chef was featured in the documentary “Jiro Dreams of Sushi.”
item.dc:creator: By DAVID S. JOACHIM
item.media:description: President Obama scored a dinner at Sukiyabashi Jiro, whose chef was featured in a documentary, “Jiro Dreams of Sushi.”

item.title: Ukraine’s Military Drive in East Enters Neutral Gear, as Pact on Crisis Is Tested
item.description: As Ukraine stepped up efforts to quell unrest, a Geneva accord to defuse the crisis frayed further as the United States and Russia exchanged accusations of meddling in the region.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.dc:creator: By ANDREW ROTH and NEIL MacFARQUHAR
item.media:credit: Sergey Ponomarev for The New York Times
item.media:description: Vyachislav V. Ponomaryov, the self-proclaimed mayor of Slovyansk, told journalists on the phone that Simon Ostrovsky, an American reporter for Vice News, was being held by local militia.

item.title: The Lede: American Reporter Held by Ukraine Separatists
item.description: The Vice News reporter Simon Ostrovsky, who has produced a series of vivid dispatches from Ukraine in recent weeks, was detained by pro-Russia separatists in the town of Slovyansk on Tuesday.
item.dc:creator: By ROBERT MACKEY

item.title: Study Finds Less Green in the Congo Rain Forest
item.description: Scientists say that a long drought that has affected trees in Central Africa could help them understand how global warming may harm vegetation.
item.dc:creator: By HENRY FOUNTAIN

item.title: Iranian Prison Chief Is Removed After Reports of Attack on Inmates
item.description: The move by the judiciary, called a promotion, came amid criticism over a violent raid on political prisoners at Evin, Tehran’s largest prison facility.
item.dc:creator: By THOMAS ERDBRINK

item.title: India Ink: Image of the Day: April 23
item.description: Arvind Kejriwal, chief of the Aam Aadmi Party, filed his nomination to fight elections from the temple town of Varanasi in Uttar Pradesh.
item.dc:creator: By THE NEW YORK TIMES
item.media:description: Arvind Kejriwal, center, leader of the Aam Aadmi Party, addressing supporters before filing his nomination to fight elections from Varanasi, Uttar Pradesh. Mr. Kejriwal will be squaring off against Narendra Modi, prime minister-designate of the main opposition Bharatiya Janata Party.

item.title: The Lede: New York Police Twitter Backlash Spreads Around the World
item.description: A New York Police Department effort to engage users on Twitter turned into an international social media campaign.
item.dc:creator: By JENNIFER PRESTON

item.title: Australia Examines Material Washed Ashore for Link to Missing Jet
item.description: The agency overseeing the hunt for the wreckage of Malaysia Airlines Flight 370 did not specify what the find was or why it was of interest.
item.dc:creator: By MICHELLE INNIS and CHRIS BUCKLEY
item.media:description: A billboard displayed messages about the missing Malaysia Airlines plane as relatives of passengers met on Wednesday at the Metro Park Hotel in Beijing.

item.title: Interfaith Panel Denounces a 9/11 Museum Exhibit’s Portrayal of Islam
item.description: An advisory group of religious leaders said a documentary at the soon-to-open National September 11 Memorial Museum was offensive to Muslims and could generate prejudice against them.
item.dc:creator: By SHARON OTTERMAN
item.media:description: Visitors outside the National September 11 Memorial Museum, which includes a documentary that describes Al Qaeda as an Islamist group.

item.title: U.S. Military Exercises to Begin in Eastern Europe
item.description: The deployments, in response to events in Ukraine, are a reflection of American commitment to defense within the NATO alliance, a Pentagon official said.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.dc:creator: By DAN BILEFSKY

item.title: India Ink: Former Executive Sells Aam Aadmi Party as Pro-Business
item.description: Meera Sanyal, a candidate in Mumbai who once headed the Indian unit of the Royal Bank of Scotland, contends her party’s anticorruption platform is good for entrepreneurs.
item.dc:creator: By MANSI CHOKSI
item.media:description: Meera Sanyal, the Aam Aadmi Party candidate from Mumbai South, speaking with people at Kamathipura, a red-light district.

item.title: Australia to Bolster Air Force With More Lockheed Jets
item.description: The country will buy 58 more F-35 fighter jets for $11.6 billion, in a deal the prime minister called one of Australia’s largest military purchases.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.dc:creator: By MICHELLE INNIS

item.title: Russia Warns Ukraine of Potential Military Response
item.description: Sergey V. Lavrov, the Russian foreign minister, continued to ratchet up pressure on Kiev, drawing comparisons to the 2008 conflict with Georgia.
item.dc:creator: By NEIL MacFARQUHAR

item.title: Obama Arrives in Asia as Disasters Complicate Mission
item.description: President Obama, who began a four-country tour on Wednesday, will encounter leaders under pressure from angry, often grief-stricken constituents.
item.category: Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas
item.dc:creator: By MARK LANDLER
item.media:description: President Obama arrived for dinner with Prime Minister Shinzo Abe of Japan at a sushi bar in downtown Tokyo.

item.title: Diplomatic Efforts on Syria Have Failed, U.N. Chiefs Say
item.description: Civilians in war zones remain in need of urgent assistance, the heads of five United Nations agencies warned in a joint statement.
item.dc:creator: By NICK CUMMING-BRUCE

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Backlash Over Hong Kong’s Treatment of Mainland Visitors
item.description: A video of a confrontation on a Hong Kong street is raising questions of whether the harsh treatment of mainland visitors has gone too far.
item.dc:creator: By GERRY MULLANY

item.title: Pacific Rim Deal Could Reduce Chance of Unintended Conflict in Contested Seas
item.description: The agreement, which includes China, Japan and the United States, comes at a time of growing concern about territorial disputes between China and some of its neighbors.
item.category: Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas
item.dc:creator: By AUSTIN RAMZY and CHRIS BUCKLEY

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Women Go Topless for Equal Rights
item.description: A group of young Chinese feminists staged a protest calling for an end to gender discrimination in employment. They highlighted the issue by going topless and holding up banners.
item.dc:creator: By DIDI KIRSTEN TATLOW

item.title: Recovery in Euro Zone Gathers Pace
item.description: Business activity in the 18 nations that use the common currency expanded in April at its fastest rate in nearly three years, according to a private sector survey.
item.dc:creator: By DAVID JOLLY
